item.title:
R to @rakitadragan: The biggest EF focus should be on client validation and networks. In future we will see even more clients types and network strains, having infrastructure for testing, fuzzing, benchmarking on both clients and the network will be essential.
I feel that we are already going there, and the teams last year were amazing. Still, testing, DevOps, and security needs to be considered essential and receive even more focus and support. üßµ 4/5

item.title:
R to @rakitadragan: Protocol evolution and decision making right now are very chaotic, you need to follow discord, live chats, forums, EIPs, github PRs and tweets to figure out what needs to be added. And it is not clear how this happens.
The technical board of 20 (or 50 people) should be responsible for decisions, and it would be good to have a fail safe veto mechanism of ~3-5 people (Vitalik for example, among others)
Transparency in the process will bring stability. üßµ 3/5

item.title:
My (not strong) take on what the Ethereum Foundation should focus on in the next 5 years (as only critiquing is not constructive):
* A robust funds distribution mechanism/group to fund projects and teams. The budget is done yearly and funded by basefee (unused basefee continues to be burned). * Protocol governance where a technical board makes decisions. * Protocol verification aka testing suites, benchmark suites, pen tests, fuzzing and infra should be the main focus of EF. üßµ 1/5

item.title:
RT by @rakitadragan: Defining hardware requirements for Ethereum entities is important because it parametrizes what we mean by decentralization, enables informed decision making about protocol upgrades and allows for meaningful benchmark comparisons.
We have been gathering feedback on the current recommendations for validators:
- $1,000 total spend - 8 cores/16 threads CPU - 4TB SSD - 32GB RAM minimum
Less powerful machines work today, but these specs would guide protocol changes related to validators.
